learning_outcomes.description: Classify drugs and chemical agents used in the therapy of companion animals and livestock, and explain their pharmacokinetics, physiological and pharmacological effects in different body systems.

Calculate correct doses, identify suitable routes of administration, and dispense drugs and chemicals in accordance with veterinary instruction and accompanied by appropriate directions to clients for a range of clinical scenarios.
Accurately record veterinary patient medical information relating to drug administration and therapeutic effects using appropriate terminology.
Demonstrate an understanding of and comply with safety legislation relevant to the use of veterinary drugs and chemical agents.
Know the basic principles of toxicology and how toxins affect organ systems with particular reference to the clinical signs, emergency treatment and management of specific toxicants in small animals.

Students will be able to work effectively in small groups to plan, develop, and deliver veterinary practice relevant tasks, demonstrating professional communication, shared responsibility, and collaborative problem-solving appropriate to veterinary technology roles.

assessments.assessment_title: Team Based Learning:  A Case-Based Approach to Therapeutics for the VT (Anaesthesia and Analgesia)
assessments.task_description:
This assessment is delivered as a Team Based Learning (TBL) session. Students will be assessed on their understanding and ability to apply knowledge of the pharmacology, side effects, and contraindications of anaesthetic and analgesic drugs. Students will also be assessed on their ability to calculate drug dosages in the forms commonly used, and on their understanding of relevant Queensland and National legislation governing their use.

The assessment will take the form of TWO (2) multiple‑choice quizzes:

  • Individual quiz: completed by each student independently. (10%)
  • Group quiz: completed collaboratively in randomly allocated groups. (10%)


This session will be conducted in‑person on campus, unless otherwise specified.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.assessment_title: Assessment Sequence:  Team Based Learning (Antimicrobials, Parasitology, Toxicology)
assessments.category: Participation/ Student contribution, Quiz, Tutorial/ Problem Set
assessments.task_description:
Students are required to participate in 3 additional Team Based Learning (TBL) assessments.


Session 1

Toxicology (5%) - Friday February 6.

Team based learning session where students will be assessed on their understanding of the basic principles of toxicology, especially how toxins affect the body, and provide information on common toxicants that affect small animals and how to recognise clinical signs.

Session 2

Antimicrobials (5%) - Friday February 20.

This assessment is delivered as a team‑based learning session focused on the responsible use of antibiotics. Students will be assessed on their understanding of antibiotic pharmacology, pharmacokinetics, legislation governing antimicrobial use, and principles of antimicrobial resistance (AMR).

Session 3

Parasiticides (5%) - Friday March 13.

Team based learning session where students will be assessed on their understanding and ability to apply their knowledge of the pharmacology, side effects and contraindications of parasiticides and their understanding of the Queensland and National legislation governing their use.

These sessions includes TWO (2) multiple‑choice quizzes:

  • An individual quiz completed independently. (2.5% each quiz)
  • Group quizzes completed collaboratively in randomly allocated teams. (2.5% each quiz)

These sessions will be conducted in‑person on campus, unless otherwise specified.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
This examination will be of 60 minutes duration and in the form of multiple choice questions (MCQ) and/or short answer questions, and may include some problem-solving case-based scenarios.

Materials covered in the Team Based Learning (TBL) sessions WILL NOT be re-examined (anaesthesia, antimicrobials, toxicology, parasiticides).

Any other materials covered in Weeks 1 - 9 may be examinable.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)  

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.weighting: <dd>15% (3% BLS online, 6% ALS online, 6% BLS/ALS in person training) </dd>
assessments.due_date:
Practical component of RECOVER assessment to be held in the 3rd year exam block (week beginning April 13, 2025).

Each student will be required to attend one full day for the "in person" RECOVER Rescuer certification during the assessment week.
assessments.category: Participation/ Student contribution, Performance, Practical/ Demonstration, Quiz, Reflection, Role play/ Simulation
assessments.task_description:
Knowledge of pharmacology is critically important in CPR (cardiopulmonary resuscitation) training because the effective use of drugs can directly influence the outcome of resuscitation efforts.

  1. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) Basic Life Support (BLS) - online certification. The BLS module will be completed online during the nine week teaching block. It may be completed at any time once each student has been enrolled for the online component. - (3%).
  2. CPR Advanced Life Support (ALS) - online certification. The ALS module will be completed online during the nine week teaching block. It may be completed at any time once each student has been enrolled for the online component. - (6%).
  3. RECOVER Rescuer Certification - this will be a scheduled practical with instructor-led clinical simulations held during the exam block. The online BLS and ALS modules must be completed prior RECOVER Rescuer Certification. Students are expected to complete the online modules as Self Directed Learning (SDL) during the nine week teaching block. - (6%).


Students will complete the online Basic Life Support and Advanced Life Support modules prior to completing instructor led clinical scenarios to gain RECOVER certification.


Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) - CPR BLS and CPR ALS Online Certification

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.


Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) - RECOVER Rescuer Certification

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: BLS and ALS online courses can be completed at any time throughout the semester and completion certificates must be uploaded to Bb - no later than Monday April 6.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
RECOVER Rescuer Certification

The use of therapeutics in CPR is essential for informed, timely decision-making during resuscitation, and students will learn how to select and administer appropriate drugs within simulated clinical scenarios aligned with RECOVER guidelines.

Students will complete the online Basic Life Support and Advanced Life Support modules prior to completing instructor led clinical scenarios to gain RECOVER certification.
learning_activities.topic_description: RECOVER Rescuer Certification The use of therapeutics in CPR is essential for informed, timely decision-making during resuscitation, and students will learn how to select and administer appropriate drugs within simulated clinical scenarios aligned with RECOVER guidelines. Students will complete the online Basic Life Support and Advanced Life Support modules prior to completing instructor led clinical scenarios to gain RECOVER certification.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 10(19 Jan - 29 Mar)
learning_activities.topic:
Team Based Learning Sessions (4 sessions)

In 2026, the learning structure for Therapeutics will be enhanced through the introduction of team-based learning sessions, associated assessment tasks, and additional tutorials. These activities will build on lecture content and make use of authentic clinical application scenarios to strengthen students’ ability to apply theoretical knowledge in practice. The redesigned approach will support deeper engagement and skill development across key therapeutic domains, including anaesthesia and analgesia, antimicrobials, parasiticides, and toxicology, ensuring students build the confidence and competence required for contemporary veterinary technology practice.”

The redesigned approach will support deeper engagement and skill development across key therapeutic domains, including anaesthesia and analgesia, antimicrobials, parasiticides, and toxicology, ensuring students build the confidence and competence required for contemporary veterinary technology practice.”

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 10(19 Jan - 29 Mar)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture Series

Series of lectures covering basic knowledge of pharmacology (pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics) and drugs classified by body system (e.g. cardiovascular, gastro-intestinal, respiratory, endocrine) OR by effects (e.g. antimicrobials; anti-inflammatories, chemotherapeutics) will be delivered over the semester. Modes of action, therapeutic effects, side effects, legislative classification, and other clinical applications will be discussed.
